did.unittitle: Benjamin Franklin Papers Part 8 -- Letters to Franklin
did.abstract:
This is part of the large inventory for the Benjamin Franklin Papers (Mss B F85). For complete information concerning this collection, please view the
Collection Description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A hygrometer on a new construction; M. de Luc's hygrometer. Death of Mrs. Clark's only brother. Mrs. Nairne, Polly and Fanny not a little flattered at Franklin's mentioning them.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed, in part, in Works (Sparks, VI, 449).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning Mr. [Thomas] Barclay's demand for all public accounts to be lodged at the consular Office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regretting his departure for England, as it will delay his meeting with Franklin. Mr. [Richard] Bache and his family in perfect health when he left Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning politics in Ireland; the action of the Volunteers; description of their Assembly; acknowledging Franklin's favor of the 16th ult., relative to the Commerical Treaty not yet being concluded; is sick of Ireland and the way she is controlled by England. Col. Grattan's failure to be elected Colonel of the Dublin Independents; fears his opposition in the Reform Bill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obliged to have recourse again to Franklin's generosity in his present unfortunate situation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mentions the engraving of Franklin's stove sent by him to M. Cadet de Vaux. M. Cadet hopes Franklin will superintend the construction of a stove which is being built, according to his principles. Begs Franklin to send him a description of the stove and also of the grate which he intends to have built for open fires; wishes to make both public; debt the Government will owe Franklin as they are now busy perfecting the means of substituting coal for wood.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for an audience.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arranging to dine with Franklin and spend the night with Mme. Helvétius. Hoped they would see him at St. Germain.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter from Lieutenant-General of Police and two tickets from Messrs. Le Grand and Molinos.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's letter appointing a day and hour never reached him until too late to keep the appointment; begs him to name another time.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Balloons, Experiment of M. [Jacques Alexandre César] Charles. Practical flying belongs to France; theoretical flying to England; cites Bishop Wilkins and Mr. [Henry] Cavendish, Mr. Mitchell's paper on light being subject to gravitation. Description of a miserable comet noted by Mr. Nathan[iel] Pigot[t] in his observatory at Yorkshire. Account of a piece of mechanism consisting of four wings and warranted to fly.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed, almost entire, in Hale's Franklin in France, II, 276.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for news of Jacques Charles d'Osmont, who at one time settled at Petersburg, Va.; rumors of his death; begs Franklin to ascertain the truth of this report; the great importance to him of this information.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin the fourth volume of M. Filangieri's work together with his letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter entrusted to him by Dr. [Samuel] Cooper, and also some Boston papers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of his former request for the position of Vice-Consul in one of the three departments of the United States. Account of the financial troubles which obliged him to make this request.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His services in the American army; one of his legs badly injured during the war; complains of the ungracious treatment he received, the lack of clothes, provisions and pay; applies to Franklin to enable him to obtain his just dues.
(In French. In dupilcate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In the collection of President Rolland which he sent Franklin, he will find a dissertation on the use of the French language in inscriptions, treaties, etc.; the author wishes to make some changes and additions on the subject and desires to know if the Resolutions of the Republic and some of their inscriptions are in French.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminds Franklin of his promise to engage Mr. [Thomas] Barclay on his return to aid Mr. [J.] Schaffer.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a copy of the proceedings in which is inserted his speech for the publication of peace.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to procure her a copy of the treaty of the United States with England and one of their treaty with Spain.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the Vice-Consul of Sardinia at the French port of Cette; advantage of having an American Consul stationed at that port; offers his services.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for the necessary passports for America; proposes to set off in two days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for Mr. [Thomas] Barclay's address; hears that he is Agent for Virginia.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation for dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a brother Mason; objectly wretched, desiring only to die; is the father of four children—a girl, whom he has placed in a convent, and three boys, all at military schools; begs Franklin to render him some assistance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin two manuscripts on geometry; hopes they will amuse and interest him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her husband, a fellow-countryman of Franklin; account for his work, death, and her present unfortunate situation with a large family to bring up and educate; begs Franklin to procure her a continuation of certain priviledges, or a pension from the King.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: If Franklin intends coming to London in the ensuing spring or summer, they beg his acceptance of their town house, which with their country house and equipage are all at his service. Health of his family. Their great desire to see Franklin; will be ashamed to talk with him of England and its Government, which daily sinks deeper in disgrace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has shipped the three barrels and the box of seeds on a vessel for Rouen; has none of the nuts of which Franklin spoke, but will bring a quantity on his next voyage. Thanks him for his kind offer which the shortness of his stay prevents his accepting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a member of the College of Surgery at Lyons; desires to lay before Franklin a plan, which, if carried out, would bring American surgery to the last degree of perfection; his friendshiip with various French surgeons of note; if Franklin approves his suggestion, will send him the details of the plan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: When her brother, Thaddeus Kosciuszko, entered the service of the United States, he left with her the direction of his property and lands; no word has come from him since his departure; on account of his reported death, the creditors of her eldest brother wish to seize his estate; in this emergency, begs Franklin to obtain some certified information of his existence or death; encloses an extract from a letter of M. lc Comte de Murinet which ought to be suffcient in itself to prove her brother's existence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On the 3d ult., sent Franklin two memoirs entrusted to his care by M. Pacaud, asking for the position of American Consul in St. Domingo; begs Franklin to send the memoirs to Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ignorant what is the dominant religion in America or whether Congress intends having an exclusive religion. Is a Roman Catholic priest, Principal of the College of Ervy-le-Châtel; offers to expatriate himself for good of his religion and the service of the Americans; hopes Congress will be able to place him in an advantageous position thinks he could persuade several of his friends to accompany him, if the prospect appeared hopeful.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting his invitation for dinner on the 25th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Before this reaches Franklin he will hear of the dismission of the late Ministry; Mr. [William] pitt is Prime Minister; no other appointment is fixed; names of some who are expected to hold office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Among the packages brought on shore, is one directed to Franklin containing snuff and tabacco; would have been heavily fined if he had been detected bringing it ashore; supposes Franklin has letters concerning it; as it cannnot be sent, begs for Franklin's instructions on that head.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a Resolution of Congress to obtain the king's permission, in order that the French officers who served in America might accept the insignia of an order to be established in memory of the Revolution; informed that the Royal consent has been obtained; desires Franklin to send him the details of the affair that he may make them known to his court.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a Resolution of Congress to obtain the king's permission, in order that the French officers who served in America might accept the insignia of an order to be established in memory of the Revolution; informed that the Royal consent has been obtained; desires Franklin to send him the details of the affair that he may make them known to his court.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The United States, having had a large share in the dedication of this almanac, takes great pleasure in sending them a copy.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Ambassador of the Emperor of Austria

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to forward letters to Baron de Beelen, the other to one Professor Maätter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will wait on him the following Thursday. Acknowledge Mr. [William Temple] Franklin's kindness in sending Dr. [Samuel] Cooper's letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will dine with Franklin on Thursday. Encloses the letter of M. de Vergennes relative to the 22d Article of the Preliminary Treaty.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Mayo, Joseph. Paris, Hotel de Portugal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Owing to his late illness, is unable to dine with Dr. Franklin on Thursday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin's presence at the opening of his shop; all his wares made of straw.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prevented from accepting Franklin's invitation by an indisposition which has kept him confined since his arrival in Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certain reflections on the construction of ac¯rostatic machines; if these ideas can be of any use, presents them to Franklin as a slight mark of his respect.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sent to him and to the Comte d'Estaing a pamphlet he wrote on the Chevalier d'Assas and the regiment of Auvergne, part of which served under the eyes of Gen. Washington; fears the copy never reached him.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Breteuil, Louis-Auguste Le Tonnelier, baron de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's letter, 1 in which he asks that [J.] Schaffer should be sent to the Islands; will do all he can, but gives certain reasons why it may be legally impossible.
(In French.)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1 Draft of this letter in French (XXX, 154a), setting forth M. Schaffer's respectable connections in America and Franklin's reasons for making this request. [1 p.].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His indisposition. Acknowledgment of Franklin's kindness. Report of Franklin's illness. Declines writing about politics; opinions in England for and against Franklin.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 47; Bigelow, VIII, 403).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to send the enclosed letter for General [Nathanael] Greene, by the first vessel for America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending the enclosed packet to Franklin's care. One of his friends, M. Chateaufort, desires a letter of recommendation to Dr. [Richard] Price; he expects to spend several months in England from motives of curiosity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's Kindness to him in Paris. Begs for some details of M. [Jacques Alexandre César] Charles's experiment in aerial navigation; his serious reasons for desiring this information. Description and drawing of the Weisner, an isolated mountain in the country of Hessia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his hurried departure for London; sends the enclosed by a messenger and if Franklin has any commands for Mr. [John] Sargent or any other person, begs they may be sent at once.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a late improvement which consists of printing with entire words instead of single letters; its gracious reception in England; if it would be equally acceptable to America, will send an exact copy of the founts and the mode of conducting it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering several cannon, the purchase of which might prove serviceable to the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Uneasiness concerning his brother [Peter Stephen]'s fate, has not heard from him for a year; encloses a letter for him and begs for some information regarding his whereabouts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's kind letter by M. Lamot and reminding him of his promise to visit them before he leaves the country. Franklin having attained all he longed and wished for, it is high time he enjoyed himself. The wheels are found and will be forwarded as soon as the river is navigable.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Marquis de la Fayette desires the papers which the writer sent Franklin, in order to find out if he is eligible to the Society of the Cincinnati; begs Franklin to forward them to the Marquis, and to grant him favorable consideration.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Breteuil, Louis-Auguste Le Tonnelier, baron de.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Since his last letter, has ascertained that [John] Schaffer has been found guilty of swindling and transferred to the prison of the Conciergerie; under these circumstances, cannot possibly interfere; advises Franklin to apply to the Keeper of the Seals for a pardon or a commutation of his punishment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes for the New Year. Sees by the papers that it is proposed to build a city and a palace for Congress; if his feeble talents can be of any use, hopes Franklin will not forget him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to forward a letter by the express he sends to Capt. [Joshua] Barney at Havre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes to establish a technical school in the United States for training the young in useful arts and industries.
(In French. In Franklin's handwriting.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking a letter of recommendation from Franklin. Is going to establish himself in business at Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a passport, and the letter which was promised him for the Count d'Adhémar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed by M. de Sarsfield that Franklin intends coming to see his flying ship, the following day; the mechanism at present entirely concealed; begs him to postpone his visit for several days.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Preserves with the greatest care the medal given her by Franklin; another precious possession is the little picture of Franklin drawn by Mlle. de Givonne; quotes the verses written underneath, composed by herself. Begging Franklin to grant a brief audience to two of her friends, Abbé de la Mailière and his father, the General.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will bid good-bye to Dr. Franklin at Passy. Asks leave to introduce some ladies to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Dr. Franklin to give a letter of recommendation to one of her friends from Languedoc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the inhabitants of Falmouth in Casco Bay, who, in October, 1775, had the greater part of their houses and effects destroyed by the merciless orders of Admiral Graves; opportunity presented of befriending these people.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Franklin and his grandson to dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes from near Bayreuth asking for information about the United States, and if colonists would be accepted and under what conditions.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has arranged to go to the Salon with Franklin and take breakfast at M. Vernet's. Will give him particulars when he calls at her house on Wednesday evening.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will await Franklin Monday morning to go to see the paintings and then take breakfast at M. Vernet's.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes Franklin will come and take tea at her house that afternoon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking Franklin to take tea and bring his son [William Temple Franklin] and Benjamin [Franklin Bache].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry to hear that Franklin and his grandson have company at their house on Christmas day and cannot dine with her. Hopes Franklin will call in the evening to take tea and hear some music.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is extremely sorry that he cnnot have the honor of accepting his invitation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing a member of the Marquis d'Aranda's family, Dr. Simon de Casas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will call on Dr. Franklin accompanied by the young gentlemen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invite him to dine with them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommends Prosper Mouret, a printer, who wishes to go to the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Secretary of Admiralty and interpreter of English at Marseilles, asks to be authorized to attend to American shipping interests.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Are theatrical directors; propose to establish a theatre at Philadelphia and bring over a troupe of actors from France; ask Franklin's approval and support.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a letter of introduction for Mr. John Shaw, a merchant who is going to Teneriffe for a cargo of wines which he will take from there to Philadelphia and other ports.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bidding good-bye to Franklin on her departure from Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know where he can procure two of Franklin's medals; imprudently promised them in Normandy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a prospectus of a new edition of Plutarch's works. dedicated to the Marquis de la Fayette; begs Franklin's interest on behalf of the work both in France and America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inscription for the pedestal of an obelisk to be erected to Liberty on a square in Boston.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes to go to the United States to make wine. Offers to submit his process and methods to doctors and chemists, if Franklin approves of his plans.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Deux-Ponts, Marianne Camasse, duchesse La douairière de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin and his grandson to spend Easter with her, as well as Keralio, Caillot and [de] Fontenet; they will all drink tea and play chess.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Deux-Ponts, Marianne Camasse, duchesse La douairière de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him some new leaves to read. Asks him to return those he has read and to observe the strictest secrecy about them. Will return to Versailles soon to await the home-coming of her son whose arrival is expected in the beginning of June.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Dr. Franklin two volumes of the History of America and three pamphlets which her son has brought from Lord Shelburne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to forward a letter to Mr. Sheldom.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remaining Franklin that, on the recommendation of the Chevalier de Chastellux, he had promised to give him letters of introduction for Philadelphia and Boston.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests an opinion of his proposal to establish a certain industry in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests Dr. Franklin to give him a letter of recommendation to some one in Boston where he is going.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In company with Messrs. de Villefranche and de Rochefontaine called on Dr. Franklin on their arrival from America to present their respects.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposition for catering to Franklin's household.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accounts and agreements between Dr. Franklin and Finck, his butler.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account as steward for wages, table supplies, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oath of office as Secretary to the Commissioners to conclude peace with Great Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to assist him to America; willing to adopt any career be may advise.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging with gratitude Franklin's permission to dedicate his book to him.
(In French. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering his services as civil engineer and architech. Wishes to settle in the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives address of M. [Palteau] de Veimerange. Asks William Temple Franklin to send him some accounts which he left on the latter's desk.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sees no way out of his present difficulties except to become a citizen of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taking leave of the Commissioners before departing from Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sold type to Franklin; requests his help in his plan of going to America to start a type foundry.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Description of bird grass and how it is grown in Virginia. Seeds said to have been originally carried there by birds of prey. Easy to grow and makes good fodder for horses. It is proposed to grow it in France, and wishes to obtain some of the seed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupied for thirty years in making comparative tables of the monies of Europe; sends Franklin nine of these tables, which he begs him to introduce into the United States; hopes to realize enough from them to print the remaining fifty-three tables.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie-Joseph-Paul-Yves-Roch-Gilbert du Motier, marquis de, and [François-Jean de Beauvoir, chevalier] de Chastellux

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request Franklin to obtain the decoration of the Order of Cincinnatus for Dr. [Jean Françuis] Coste, Surgeon-in-chief of the French army in America and member of the American Philosophical Society, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to go to America and practise medicine there; requests letters of recommendation for Philadelphia.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. Cannot encourage him to establish himself among strangers, of whose language he is ignorant; recommends him to go to one of the French islands.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to dine with Franklin on Saturday; will come Sunday if convenient.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for the return of a paper containing certain proposed experiments by [General Jean Baptiste Marie] Mcusnier, to be read before the Academy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupied with his balloons. Begs him to take tea with him. Messages for his grandson.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites Franklin and his grandson to take tea at his house and witness a balloon ascension. Prince de Bariatinskoÿ will be present.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites Franklin to take tea with him on Saturday and see some balloons go up.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites him and his grandson to dine with him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to accept Messrs. Franklin's invitation for Saturday, as it is Academy day.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a catalogue of seeds which Franklin had promised to forward to Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites Franklin to come and see him and Mme. Le Roy in their new apartments.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks his decision about going to see the experiments of M. de Montgolfier.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been told by Prince Bariatinskoÿ that Franklin is to dine with him. Asks if he could take him in his carriage.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. de Montgolfier has heard that Franklin would like to sce an experiment with his balloon in private and with only a few persons present. Asks what day would suit him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests letters of recommendation for Jean Nicolas Joseph Hankars, of Liège, to prominent people in Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. Rochas who intends to settle in Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a few copies of the plan and situation of Port-Vendre
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Question of commercial relations between America and France. Offering his services for the position of Consul at Cette.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Messey, Louis François Antoine Nicolas Marquis de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the medal struck in honor of America's independence; refers to the kindness shown him during his stay at Passy; regrets that he could not have shed his blood in the American cause.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on the great part he has played in America's independence; desires to be a witness of all the homage which his countrymen will render to his heroic virtues.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to his plan for starting a galss factory in America which received Franklin's approval. Requests the latter to notify him when a vessel arrives from America so that he may get passage on it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing him of the place and time at which the fête in celebration of peace will be held. He is expected and urgently requested to be present on the occasion.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to recommend them as agents for American vessels and crews coming to Calais.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him the third volume of their Dictionary of Agriculture. Report of the medals which are to be struck in honor of peace; desires specimens for their famous collection of medals.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to see him on particular business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends two notes and a petition from the Lodge of Patriotism of versailles (5p.) asking for the appointment of M.Gautier of Barcelona as consul for the United States at that port.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to consult Franklin concerning establishing himself in business in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Number of copies of the Constitutions sent Franklin; sixty copies still at his disposal; thinks he has forgotten the Stadtholder of Holland and the States-General.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him three letters which he brought from Geneva; asks permission to pay his personal respects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to dine at Passy as he proposed, on account of business; intends going to England Sunday morning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to take the oath of allegiance to the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His desire to settle in America; applies for a grant of land from Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Served in the Commissariat Department with Rochambeau's army in America; petitions Franklin to help him obtain a brevet as an invalided officer.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a manufacturer of wall paper; asks for information about trade in the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On England's defeat by the American Colonies and their independence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratualting Franklin on the restoration of peace. Question of a bill of exchange sent to Mr. [Ferdinand] Grand. Hopes to hear from Franklin in Philadelphia.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sent the printer the Treaty of Alliance with France and that with Holland; desires the Treaty with Sweden and the Preface as soon as possible. Elections to the Academy; will take great pleasure in seconding Franklin's views for Mr. [Joseph] Priestly.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests the return of the translation of the Constitution of Virginia, in order that he may make some corrections, and to send him the continuation of the Constitution of Marryland.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presenting Messrs. Franklin and Deane with fifty copies of the American Confederations, translated.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Dr. Franklin the translation of the New Constitution of Delaware.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Dr. Franklin to let him have the " Minutes of the Convention held at Philadelphia for the Pennsylvania Legislation."

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a copy of the Treaty with Sweeden, for insertion in his work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A plan to gather together all poor unfortunates and transplant them to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On the new constitution of laws for America. A tribute to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Send, from London, their compliments to Dr. Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging his interest on behalf of an American, [J.] Schaffer, who risks being dishonored in the eyes of all the world.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for the money loaned in the past and begs another small advance.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Schmoldt, Johann of the Duchy of Bremen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Calls his attention to the tax of 10 per cent. levied on the property of those who wish to leave the Duchy to go to America or other foreign countries.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petitions for a free passage to America for himself and his family where he proposes to establish a factory for coloring and printing fabrics for tapestries, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking his commands for England. Refers him to the inscription on the Peace of Munster; desires his speedy appearance in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting an interview for M. Desouche who wishes to see Franklin about several matters.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their intention, now that peace is declared, to send vessels to America with a rich cargo; desire a letter of recommendation to the house of Messrs. Bache and Shee; advisability of sending their ship under the American flag.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for the address of Mr. John Perkins who was then in Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have received a letter which will interest Dr. Franklin. Desire to see him to communicate its contents.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promising to wait on Franklin, agreeable to his invitation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to settle in America; begs Franklin's influence to obtain land and employment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of rare American plants and trees to be obtained from Mr. [William] Bartram of Philadelphia; price, best means of transportation, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His admiration for Franklin. Good wishes for America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring letters of introduction and recommendation for himself and his friend M. Morgand; business which takes them to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending the bearer, one of a select number of young Englishmen who wish to settle in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of tracts of land in America owned by him and request for directions how to proceed relative thereto.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The King of France having ordered a monument to be erected over the tomb of Admiral Ternay who commanded the French naval forces which brought over Rochambeau and his troops, the writer proposes that the United States honor the nephew of the Admiral by conferring on him the Order of Cincinnatus.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two expert silk weavers propose to go with families to the United States and establish that industry in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks advice about going to America to start a printing and book seller's business.
(In French. Incomplete.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring Franklin's advice as to the establishment of a commercial house in the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes to send thirty families of skilled workmen to the United States and to establish a foundry or iron works there.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two residents of Bordeaux, one a doctor the other a manufacturer, propose to go to America and establish themselves at Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A young Frenchman who wishes to go to America requests Franklin to give him an interview.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advising Franklin of the arrival at the Custom-house at Paris of a case addressed to him.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Saint Esprit, Sœur Marie, abbesse du. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin their good wishes for the New Year.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes Count Choteck's commission has been forwarded to America. Their plan of making an air-balloon if they can get a sum adequate to the expense; one of their Society, a young man, will go to Paris in order to obtain a perfect knowledge of their structure and management; desires to know if these are kept secret; looks upon these balloons as one of the greatest discoveries of natural philosophy; its probable influence on war; the English jealous of this discovery. Inexcusable delay in receiving the Pennsylvania Almanac Franklin sent him a year and half ago. German edition of his book out two years while the original is not yet published; finds this in the highest degree vexing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's attention to the interests of their house, and reimbursing him for the bill which he kindly prevented from being returned.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing the greatest pleasure at Franklin's contentment with [Benjamin Franklin] Bache; wishes for his long life and happiness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The medal which Franklin bestowed on the Vicomte de Mory, his brother-in-law, is the most precious reward he received for his services in America; begs that de Mory may be made a member of the Society of Cincinnatus.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation for dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering further suggestions on the subject of ballons.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a translation of his remarks on the savages.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the glorious triumph achieved by the United States, and on his own part in that great event. Begs his acceptance of some observations he has made on phosphorus and a treatise on diplomacy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: It has been a long time since he last talked with Franklin; begs for an interview.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation for dinner.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Stephen Hopkins and James Manning, President. Providence, R.I

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin an address which they beg him to lay before the King of France, soliciting his patronage of their College [Brown University] by the establishing there of a Professor of the French language and History together with the presentation of certain French books, etc.; encouraged to make this request by his Majesty's important literary favors to Yale College, which they understand that Corporation thought proper to decline.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reasons which have induced him to contemplate emigrating to America; desires necessary advice and information.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enthusiastic praise of his father and Franklin. [P(ost) S(cript) in French, signed E.N.B. and P. Bancroft.] New Year's wishes from their mother; account of their father's movements in America and his intended visit to France; news of their brother and sisters; the latter recovered from small-pox with no disfigurement, owing to inoculation; messages to Mrs. [John] Jay and to Mr. and Mrs. [Le Ray de] Chaumont.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lancival, Jean Charles Julien Luce de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a poem for whose faults he begs indulgence and asking him to forward a copy of it to the immortal Washington.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for the letter he wrote to M. Breteuil; in spite of Franklin's wish not to meddle further in his affairs, begs a line to M. Rosambo, President of the Tournelle and M. de Gars de Courcelles; also requests that M. Beaumont may be granted an interview to speak on his behalf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to accept a copy of his work on Natural History and to forward another to the illustrious [American Philosophical] Society of Philadelphia of which he is President; would consider it a great honor to become a member of this Society.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes the similarity in their names will induce Franklin to take an interest in him, and procure him a position in some Academy of Design, or at least the place of draughtsman at the Royal Ecole de Génie, at Mezieères;.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to write to M. de Rosambo, and M. de Gars de Courcelles in favor of himself and [J.] Schaffer; their fate is entirely in Franklin's hands.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin his book relative to a new method for planting and cultivating vineyards as well as new processes for the manipulation and fermentation of wines; desires to place his discoveries at the service of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of Sept. 13th and has taken steps to procure the intelligence wanted. Delivered the memorial from David and Ann [Hellier] Barry with the papers respecting the Grenville claim, to the delegates for North Carolina. Communicated M. de Bernardo's letter to Congress who did not think proper to take any measures thereon; the ports of the United States are open to all foreigners, and men of science or abilities will be welcome, but Congress seems disinclined to give particular encouragement to any Nation or individual. The Definitive Treaty ratified that day and the ratification entrusted to Col. J[osiah] Harmar, the President's Private Secretary, whom he recommends to Franklin's particular notice and attention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Indian flour has arrived and will be forwarded.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His early pleadings for the rights of America; what Ireland did for America deserves very warm returns in National connection and friendship. His fears for America caused by the talk of disbanding the army without the troops having received their arrears. Has left Dublin and is enjoying the diversion of shooting. Concerning the reforms they hope to make in their Parliament. Injury to Ireland by the changes in the British Ministry; characters of the Viceroys. Lack of able and worthy men in Dublin to put forward as candidates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing the Comtesse de Fries, whose husband is a banker in Vienna, one of the richest and most respectable men in Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for an audience that he may present Franklin with a copy of a work entitled "Lois Pénales," which he has dedicated to the brother of the King [Comte de Provence]; desires Franklin to forward a copy to Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Treaty of Peace ratified by Congress. Account of various inquiries he has made at Franklin's request. Measures proposed for the payment of debts contracted during the war. Praise of Col. [David Salisbury] Franks.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed, in part. in Works (Sparks, X, 56; Bigelow, VIII, 430).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to be the first to present Franklin with a copy of the American Almanac, undertaken at Berlin; sends it by M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval]; is open to any order for it which Franklin may send him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his miserable situation with no work and a wife and four children to support; begs Franklin for a small loan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laying before Franklin his plan for the establishment in America of a superfine cloth, cashmere and frieze manufactory; one hundred Protestant emigrants, qualified for the different parts of the business, are willing to embark with him; desires to know whether such an establishment would be welcome and what encouragement it would receive.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Toustain, Charles-Gaspard de Toustain-Richebourg, vicomte de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As a member and Corresponding Secretary of the Société Partriotique-Bretoune, is deputed to inform Franklin of the highly flattering testimonials rendered to his and Gen. Washington's qualities at their last meeting; M. le Comte de Sérent was the orator of the occasion.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to forward the enclosed letter to his brother in Boston; his letter thus far have always failed to reach him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delivered the letter to Mr. [John] Sargent. Begs Franklin's interest with M. [Charles Eugène Gabriel de la Croix, Marquis] de Casrtries to obtain the defrayal of his personal expenses during his three years' service in England; is heavily in debt.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that the enclosed letters may be forwarded to America by the first opportunity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning M. Montgolfier's discovery and the results of certain experiments made by them which they would be only too glad to communicate to the above distinguished inventor ;explains his scheme, to be employed in voyages of discovery, of attaching the balloon by a cord to the vessel.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know if a memoir of Benjamin Morel of Dunkirk, which she sent him, arrived safely and what hopes she may give her relative.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recalling themselves to his remembrance and requesting an audience with him at Passy.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation for dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning establishing a glass factory in Maryland; their intention to send their friend, Mr. Amelong, to Baltimore in the spring, together with eighty families all experienced in the business; begs for letters of introduction and recommendation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pleasure at his recovery. Loss of a ship in which he [Chase] was considerably interested; question of Mr.[John] Jay's preparing and presenting a memorial on the subject; begs Franklin's influence with the Marquis de Castries and de la Fayette. Small prospect of obtaining the Bank [of England] stock. Expects to return to Maryland in February or March.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Describing a house and garden at Versailles which he thinks would suit Franklin; its distance from the Chateau; suggests Franklin's grandson coming to look at it;offers also to show him a collection of sedanchairs, from which he can select one for Franklin. Account of an harmonica sent to the Duchesse de Villeroy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Steps he has taken to produce the information about the value of the two ships. Thanks him for his intended kindness in respect to the Consulship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering Franklin a valuable discovery he has made; a sure preventative against all toothache; realizes that this secret, if revealed, will do great injury to the dentists, but his object is to be useful to humanity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As he has the honor of Franklin's protection for the establishment of a woolen manufactory in the United States, gives him a detailed account of his business abilities; prefers holding a salaried position under any gentleman who is willing to carry out this project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his medical training and experience; offers his services to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a manuscript presented to his son as part-payment for instructing the child of the author; owing to his financial looses, he is anxious to dispose of the ms.; high opinion of its excellence expressed by several book-sellers; offers to sell it to Franklin; thinks it might prove useful to instruct the young Anglo-American nobility.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transmitting Franklin a piece written in America against the Cincinnati, and a newspaper containing the institutions of that Society; when Franklin writes on this subject to M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval], begs him to present his respectful compliants.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to use his influence to obtain for him the position of Agent for Wines, now at the disposal of Maréchal de Sainey; asks this favor on the strength of their being brother Masons.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his thirteen years of service as a surgeon in the French army; has nothing to show for it expect his impaired health; offers his services to America; desires to be put in charge of a military hospital there.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing to Franklin his friend, [Robert John] Thomton, a student of medicine, who expects to study French and surgery in Paris. His purpose to make an elegant edition of Dr. [John] Fothergill's life, in which will appear anecdotes and portraits of Franklin and others of Dr. Fothergill's friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets being unable to accept his invitation but will call on him to exchage notifications.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes that the manuscript (XXXI, 46) sent to Franklin will meet with his approbation; if he has no use for it, begs he will at least render him some assistance in his present unfortunate situation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the sentence pronounced against him by the Court of Admiralty, relative to the insurance of the ship "Nancy"; reasons why he has ordered an appeal; is nevertheless obliged to pay the full premium at once; begs Franklin's protection in this affair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote Franklin on the 22d inst. relative to the insurance on the American ship "Nancy"; conditions of the policy; in spite of proofs in their possession, the sentence was aginst them; have entered an appeal but they will be obliged to pay the money if Franklin does not interfere and obtain a quick decision from the Minister.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's and the Bache family's kindness to his young kinswoman. Urging him to spend the rest of his days in England. Recommending the bearer, Dr. Ross, who has served as physician to the English army in the East, but who now desires to pursue his profession in America; Franklin's recommendation would be of great service to him. The present political confusion.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed, in part, in Works (Sparks, X, 65; Bigelow, VIII, 446).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his acquittal and discharge; has now the right to pursue those who were the cause of his disgrace; desires the publication of his trail in order that his countrymen may be convinced of his innocence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending to Franklin's attention, Mr. Vanderhorst and his daughter who go to Paris for a short stay; on their return, begs that they may be entrusted with the money for the bill of exchange sent to Franklin. Intends on his return to America, to establish a refinery in addition to his distillery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the acquittal and discharge of [John] Schaffer; uses every argument to persuade him that Schaffer merited his esteem; desires Franklin's help to enable his client to publish an account of his trial, as his compatriots may be interested in his triumphant vindication; for this purpose, the celebrated [John] Paul Jones has promised to subscribe; Schaffer's intention to quit France as soon as his affairs are arranged; believes his experience will teach him an important lesson.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just left the Magistrate who has received no answer from him relative to the verification of his signature; implores him to hasten his reply.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets leaving Passy without seeing Franklin. Asks for a little advice concerning an island, by name Brid, which she hears the Americans desire to repeople; a young man, a relative of one of her waiting women, desires to go there; begs Franklin to grant the young man his protection.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for information as to what passes between the Duke of Dorset and the Dutch Ministers on the subject of converting the preliminary agreement into a definitive treaty.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Detailed account of his services in America, the battles he fought and the honors he received; begs Franklin to procure his admission to that noble association [the Society of the Cincinnati].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending to Franklin's notice Lieut-Col. [Josiah] Harmar, a very deserving officer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The stove is finished according to Franklin's plan; begs him to visit the stove-maker and ascertain if there are any faults to be corrected; his brother [Louis Claude Cadet-Gassicourt] desires that Franklin will dine with him on that day; will call for him at Passy, if he will name the day and hour.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's letter which announces the miscarriage of the manuscript; will take his advice concerning its disposal; as Franklin does not wish to buy it, begs him for a small loan of five louis d'or to enable him to meet a business obligation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for a certificate of good character in order to secure his release from prison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [William] Bartram's letter; reminds Franklin of his promise to make use of him to procure certain natural specimens, as yet unknown in Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a bill of sixty dollars sent to Franklin to verify the signature, hopes he will do this and deliver the bill only to [J.] Schaffer himself; this money is his sole resource; without it, he cannot publish an account of his trial and thereby reinstate himself in his countrymen's good opinion.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation for dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending to Franklin's acquaintance his good friend, Abbè [J.] Nckrep, President of the Oriental College at Vienna, a very good scholar and philosopher; his reasons for deciding to give up their plan of constructing a balloon. Sorry to hear that Franklin has a stone in the bladder; remedies for this disease; no cure as yet discovered; gives him some medical advice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He and his wife accept with pleasure Franklin's kind invitation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him a copy of his work; if he reads and approves it, he will not refuse to receive the copy destined for Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reasons why his father sent the manuscript to Franklin; has offered it to one of the Editiors of the Journal Militaire who gave him hopes of accepting it; the publication however will be too late to help them in their present difficulties; applies for a small loan to tide them over this critical period.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Understands that Franklin employs workmen in his printing-house in Philadelphia; offers his services; if this is impossible, desires to teach Latin and other branches; can furnish excellent references.
(In French.)

A.E. by Dr. Franklin. His correspondent misinformed; does not employ persons in America in that business; believes it would be difficult for one who is a stranger to the language to find such employment there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to see him on an important matter.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: MacMahon, John. At the Military school in Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hindered by a previous engagement from accepting Franklin's kind invitation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her satisfaction in Franklin's account of his grandson [Benjamin Franklin Bache]; sure that Franklin will be content with his disposition and good sense; is not so certain about his studies; his stay with his grandfather will doubtless bring out all his latent talents.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter from the Stadtholder to the states of Zealand, which has added fuel to the fire. Anxious for news of what is passing in Paris between the English and Dutch Ministers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Messrs. Quinquet and Lange, inventors of the lamp, are very anxious to submit it to Franklin's opinion.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the discovery by M. de Lestrades, King's physician at Martinique, of a remedy for the stone; nothing is lacking to the doctor's glory except the honor of prolonging Franklin's days; urges him to try this remedy; hopes on his return to Paris to hear that it has proved successful.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reasons why she has not written; constantly thinking of and missing him.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, Nov., 1906, 169.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of the important services he rendered him during his unfortunate stay in Montreal, and the promise made him of some recompense; since then has been ruined by a law-suit and is now left without means and with a family dependent on him; begs Franklin to make up a subscription among his friends and send it to him.
(In French. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the death of his father-in-law, M. Macquer; as soon as he is able, will inform Franklin of his last wishes in favor of one of his relations; reminds Franklin of their first meeting and of their conversation on the subject, which interested M. Macquer intensely.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [William] Hodgson's search for precedents relative to the capture of vessels situated like the "Nancy"; a trial to determine that point expected to come off very soon; promise of mr. Hodgson to send particulars of the decision. Is detained on matters connected with the public accounts. Likelihood of Mr. [Robert] Morris's bills on the negotiators of the loan in Holland being paid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the papers on balloons. Prevented by the cold weather from waiting on Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarded the letter by the packet from New York and charged the bill for postage to Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Necessary to have Franklin's evidence in Court concerning a bill of Messrs. Bache and Shee; thinks a written statement would be received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry, to have missed him when she called. Desires to know what M. de Morel may expect from Franklin's kindness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of La Baronne de Bissy, who has been left with six children to educate; begs Franklin's influence to place one of them in the merchant marine; the father's services in the navy.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Weinlandt, Johann Caspar. Römhild near Coburg, Franconia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the establishment of a cut-glass and mirror factory in America, and, if material be here, to establish a blue-color (Woad) factory. Conditions of establishment. A student of theology is willing to join the emigrants and serve as preacher.
(In German, accompanied by a French translation.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the request of a distinguished officer who served in America, writes to beg Franklin for the title and address of General Washington and of the President of Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deputed by the Royal Society of Medicine to send Franklin the enclosed tickets for the next public meeting; expects to read enlogies on William Hunter and [Antoine Nunez Ribeiro] Sanchez; Franklin's presence would be a great encouragement.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed by Mr. Vanderhorst of Franklin's anxiety concerning the health of his friend Dr. [Samuel] Cooper of Boston; greatly grieved at having to announce his death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of La Princesse Sapicha who desires to know if a Polish gentleman, by name [Thaddeus] Kosciusko, is still alive; begs for a line.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting to be made a member of the Society of Cincinnatus; this would be the most acceptable compensation they could offer him for the wound he received at the siege of Yorktown.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encouraged to invite him to a ball at his mother's house.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of the 13th and his kind attention to Mr. Vanderhorst and his daughter; especially grateful for the assistance rendered his son relative to the art of refining sugar; desires to know if his son could be introduced as a workman at Bercy where he could hear more of the "new principles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a bill of exchange for Franklin's acceptance.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation for dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's precious present; greatly pleased with the valuable contents of the book; thinks it proves not only the wisdom of the American legislators but the manliness of the whole country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recalls himself to Franklin's memory by sending him a memoir on an important matter. The printer, de Monville, will give him the copies which he decided to send to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to lay before him a plan for the cultivation of the vine in America; question of the proper land and climate.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Trembinski, Comte Biberstein. Havre in Normandy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Through the kindness of the Due de la Rochefoucauld, received Franklin's letter of introduction to Congress; his ardent desire to see America; fears that the state of his health may prevent his making the voyage; prophesies a great future for the new republic.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The enclosed copy of the proceedings in his trial will prove to Franklin his innocence and the cruel treatment he has undergone; desires him to communicate it to all his countrymen and obtain their assistance, in order that he may return to his own country decently; expects to leave for Philadelphia in a few days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring some information concerning a person named Campo, who says he served Franklin as valet de chambre.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of the events which brought about his ruin. His desire to settle in America; begs for Franklin's advice that he may find the surest route and the means to work honestly.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin is invited by the Licutenant-General of Police and from the Bureau of Administration of the Ecole Royale, to be present at the distribution of prizes to take place at the Tuileries.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending his friend George Livius to Franklin's kind attention. Mentions having seen Dolly Blunt, the painter, Mr. [Benjamin] West, and his wife and [John] Trumbull who has finished an excellent portrait of Franklin's acquaintance, Mr. [John?] Temple. At Mr. West's, saw a most exquisitely fine marble bust of Franklin which seems to say "Ye are very welcome to claim all ye please. I do not care".

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Royal Society of Medicine. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to a public meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has forwarded Franklin the knives, forks and two locks belonging to Mr. [John] Jay. For some time aided American prisoners who escaped from England, but for the last six months has refused to continue it, fearing the applicants were English; sends a statement of the money he has expended. Begs for the position of American Consul.
(In French.)
A. E. by Dr. Franklin. Thanks for his care, etc., would be glad to have his account in order to discharge it. Approve of his not giving more money to pretended Americans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to Franklin's kind acceptance of his book. Has written a memoir, as yet unpublished, on the manner of executing these penal laws; begs him to propose to Congress a duplicate of this manuscript together with his plan for constructing houses of correction. Reflections on M. Blanchard's experiment with a balloon.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vergennes, Charles Gravier, comte de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of the 26th ult., in favor of his nephew Mr. [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.]; conditions which must be complied with, before he can place Mr. Williams's request before the King.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to become a citizen of the United States; his reasons for quitting his important position in the Military Academy founded by the Due de Wurtemburg; advantageous offers made him by the Kind of Prussia; his determination fixed however to give his services to America; his plan to go over first and reconnoitre, and then return for a number of his countrymen who are skilled in agriculture; asks merely that the expense of his passage be defrayed and a pension assured to his family, in case he should die during the voyage.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sent a note and petition some months ago concerning M. Mont who seeks to be appointed Consul for the United states at Dunkerque. Has requested Mme. Cadet de vaux to get his reply.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his letter to the Editors of the Journal of Paris; wishes he had added his "advice to those seeking to go to America." Prevented from going to the country by M. Brillon's gout; desires Franklin, though a heretic, to pray for him.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in proc. Am phil. Soc., XL, 105; also in Putnam's Monthly, Nov., 1906,170.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the catalogue of le Due de la Vallièré's library; places his services at Franklin's disposal.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: High esteem in which Franklin is held in Italy and especially in Lombardy; takes the liberty of sending him two volumes of the celebrated President [Comte de] Carli[-Rubbi]'s famous work, entitled Lettere Americane.
(In Italian.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates Franklin on his part in the glorious revolution; urges him to turn his attention once more to philosophical pursuits. Expatiates on the plan for uniting the Philadelphia and Loganian Libraries; begs Franklin to send Mr.[James] Logan his opinion on this subject. Account of the application made to the Legislature by the [American] Philosophical Society for a grant of land on the S.E. and S. W. corners of the State-house yard for the erection of two buildings, one for the Library and one for the Society; in case this petition fails, the Society has purchased a large lot of Mr. Hopkinson near the Observatory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin an epigram of his and some reflections on balloons [3p.] as a pretext for writing to him. Desires his sentiments on the cures of Comus [Nicolas Philippe Ledru] and Mesmer; if genuine he would come to Paris to be initiated into their mysteries, with a view of aiding the poor inhabitants of the country to whom his services have been dedicated for fifteen years.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of Mme. Rebecca Allere, a countryman of Franklin's, aged about twenty, who is in the sorest straits. Her husband sailed for America in May 1783, Leaving her and their infant child in a convent, and promising to send her remittances on his arrival; no word has come from him, and his wife has been driven through despair to contemplate suicide; moved by her story; he has rendered her some slight assistance; obliged to leave Paris, so begs Franklin to befriend her; her unblemished character.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of M. de Breget's cure which can be ascribed only to magnetism; difficult to believe that which one does not understand; Versailles resounds with the miracle; desires Franklin's opinion; received her account of the cure from a young man who believes as little in magnetism as she does.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a copy of a memoir (1p.) sent Franklin on Sept. 17th, 1783; this concerns M. Jean Larrouy's request for the position of Vice-Consul at the port of Andaye; begs Franklin's influence with Congress on his behalf.
(In French.)
A. E. by Dr. Franklin, Will communicate his memoir to the Consul-General, Mr. [Thomas] Barclay, who alone has the power of making the desired appointment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Borrowed money to help her son, who has ruined her by his dissipation and extravagance; afraid to tell her husband of her imprudent behaviour;begs Franklin to send her twelve thousands livres.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of a young man who desires to go to America; had heard that land is often given away to would-be settlers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing her grandson Mr. Samuel Ridout who purposes spending a few weeks in Paris before leaving Europe.
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. "W[illiam] T[emple] F[ranklin] to visit him and invite him to dinner, etc."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Speaks gratefully of the recommendation Franklin gave him to Mr. Robert Morris, a year before; his first commercial attempt not very successful; his last enterprise fitted out at New York and bound for the Azores, wrecked by a fierce tempest; now at Lisbon for repairs; while in New York, discovered in his lodgings a packet, probably left by the English, which he now forwards to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their trade in woolens, linens, etc.; desires to enter into business relation with American merchants; begs him to recommend reliable firms in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning Franklin's original paper, with his translation; advises him not to show the paper indiscriminately, for fear it might anger some persons Franklin does not wish to offend.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expense of franking the letters to America; afraid to send them by passengers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of the 11th inst. Price of church bells; their exportation forbidden.
