scopecontent.p: Franklin's passage to America. Detained in Ireland; has been obliged to put Mr. Philip Moore in prison; Mr. [Thomas] Digges, who had so much of the prisoner's money, is also there; thinks him both fool and rogue. The Irish propositons the principal subject of conversation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Catastrophe befallen [Pilâtre] de Rozier; desires to take his place in presenting to the King of England the gold medals struck in France in honor of aerostatic improvements and discoveries. Transcribing copies of his aerial journal for certain friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to lay before Franklin the plan of a commercial enterprise with the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Misfortunes brought on America and Great Britain by the war; regret at the separation of the two countries. Advocates the restoration to the loyalists of their confiscated estates. Hopes M. [Pierre] du Calvet will obtain the money due him from Congress. Concerning the diminution of the National Debt.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 187).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Calls to memory Franklin's kind reception of his friend, M. de Cissay, who desires to embark on one of the two vessels fitted out by the King to sail around the world; M. de Cissay's willingness to go as a simple volunteer, though he is fitted to take his place as mineralogist, chemist or naturalist; begs Franklin's influence with the Marquis de Castries to obtain this favor.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of her voyage from Philadelphia; news of the [Richard] Bache family. Her son a student at the College of Abbeville; hopes to see Franklin in America in August.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deprived of seeing Franklin for the last six months; has been in strict retirement owing to her husband's death; begs him to send a small packet to England for her, by a quick and trustworthy hand; also wishes a letter forwarded to London by the next courier.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a bill of exchange drawn on Franklin; requesting an order on M. [Ferdinand] Grand for the money.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a fine new Philadelphia ship just arrived in port which he thinks would be the very thing for Dr. Franklin, both as to safety and convenience.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending by Gov. [William] Franklin a manuscript copy of his two aerial voyages; promise of Sir Joseph Banks to read them before the [Royal] Society at its next meeting; begs Franklin therefore not to suffer any copy to be printed. In England has met with none of the honors heaped upon M. [Francçis] Blanchard in France. Wishing him a prosperous voyage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to become a professor of belles-lettres and foreign languages at Philadelphia; begs Franklin's acceptance of his little book, devised for the assistance of beginners in Italian.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a memoir [3p.] of M. Jean Daste, owner of the ship "le Vernet" which was captured by the English on her return voyage from Charleston in 1778; afterwards retaken by an American ship, the "Boston," and carried into the port of Boston; sale of her cargo by the French Consul, who has retained the money in the name of the King; the Marquis de Castrics willing to settle the affair, provided he receives authentic information of what took place at Boston; applies to Franklin for aid in this matter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the afore-mentioned bill of exchange, drawn to their order by Messrs. Schweighauser and Dobrée of Nantes.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. Having received no word from Messrs. Schweighauser and Dobrée relative to this bill, cannot pay it until better informed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advocates a friendship between England and America. Possibility of rivalry between France and Great Britain in the East Indies. Enthusiastic over M. [Jacques] Necker's book [Administration des Finances].

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 195; Bigelow, IX, 136).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to pay his respects to Franklin, if he will appoint a leisure moment.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Hollis, T Brand. Bruton Street London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting his acceptance of the Areopagitica, the tractate on Education and some remarks on Johnson's Life of Milton; the spirit of the Court shown by the abuse the new Poet-Laureate bestows on Milton's prose writings. Despotism in England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerned to hear of Franklin's indisposition. Much reduced in health and spirits by the great loss he has sustained; advised to travel; on hearing of Franklin's intended departure from Havre, determined that his tour should be thither; begs for ten day's notice of Franklin's arrival in Havre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's election as a member of the Académic des Sciences, Belleslettres et des Arts of Lyons; sends a list of the Society's members and of the prizes bestowed; adds a dissertation on the laws of Lycurgus by the Author of the Testament de Fortuné Ricard.
(In French.)
[Enclosure from the Abbés de Chalut and Arnoux relating to Franklins answer to the above letter.]
[Brother of J.B.C. Lucas Desptutreux?]

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 197; Bigelow, IX, 138).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Since his brother's departure for America on March 14th, 1784, no word has been received from him; begs Franklin to allay, if possible, their extreme anxiety and give them any information in his power concerning his brother's fate.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Can scarcely realize that Franklin has left them forever. Sees him in imagination in his litter being borne gradually away. Fears for his health and the fatigue of the long journey. Asks him to turn back and stay with her and her friends and share her retreat. The friendship he would find there would make it pleasing to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a suitable vessel in which Franklin can take passage to America; regrets not being able to accompany him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Terms of accommodation agreed upon between her uncle [Alexander John Alexander] and the Bank [of England]. Mr. [Jonathan] Williams [Jr.]'s business in Dublin with Mr. [Philip] Moore. Expressions of friendships and affection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Act of charity towards [Lewis] Evans's daughter [Mrs. Amelia Barry]. Franklin's great service to his country; high hopes for America; example of Switzerland. England justly punished. Sends him a final farewell.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 199).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the enclosed letter for Franklin's signature; begs that it may be returned as soon as signed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His visit to Mr. [William] Strahan, who is dangerously ill. Mr. [Alexander] Garden asks for a letter of recommendation from Franklin in favor of Mr. William Peterkin, a dissenting clergyman, who desires to settle in the United States; enclosing letter [1p.] from Mr. Strahan's son, Andrew, on the same subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Placing his litter at Franklin's disposal; delighted at being able to render his journey to Havre a trifle easier.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests Dr. Franklin to secure a settlement of his account from John Barclay and Co., and Evrard [Jones, of Boston].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has never been able to go to bid him farewell. Feared the occasion would be too painful for both of them. Will never forget the eight years passed in Franklin's company. Asks him to send them news about himself. Postscript by M. Brillon.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's monthly, Jan., 1907, 433.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishing Franklin and his grandson a happy voyage to America. Intends continuing his trip to Germany; wishes he could accompany them to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that the enclosed letter may be delivered to her friend in Philadelphia. The once happy Sally Randolph now obliged to live in an alms house at Deptford; all her misfortunes due to the late unnatural war; sends messages to her old friend Sally Bache.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of the Société [ Royale de Physique d'Histoire Naturelle et des Arts d'Orleans], regretting Dr. Franklin's departure for America and desiring a correspondence with his illustrious [American philosophical] Society at Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his letter; her father, her sister, Miss La Motte and Miss Price join her in wishing him continued good health.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to recommend Mr. [John] Aislabie, a son of an old friend, to Samuel Johnston, Esq., Member of the Assembly in Edenton, [North Carolina].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On his return from saying good-bye to Dr. Franklin, was met by the news of his son's arrival; his anxiety concerning the effect on Franklin's health of the passage to England; good wishes for his future welfare.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will ever prize the kind present of Franklin's medallion. Reflections on old age, the Foundling Hospital at Paris, the Philadelphia Bank, and the Society of Cincinnatus. [Peter] Dollond's appreciation of Franklin's account of his double spectacles. Concerning his work the Principles of Trade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of Captain [Thomas] Truxton; preparation for Franklin's coming.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Capt. [Thomas] Truxton will endeavor to have all things on board before his arrival. Reminds him not to let the mattress be forgotten.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Overjoyed at the prospect of seeing Franklin again; expects to wait upon him after dinner, with his wife and daughter.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 218; Bigelow, IX, 148).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nothing retards the publication of his sketch of Franklin, except the additions he promised to send. Donation of books sent by him to Carlisle College. Sends Franklin a present of Dr. Fothergill's works.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Peter Thellusson fils and Co. London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his favor of the 24th inst.; happy to be of any service to him; send the desired letter of credit.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Potts, Samuel. General Post Office London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Disappointed at being unable to pay his respects to him. Desires a letter, certifying to the purpose for which he waited upon Franklin at Passy in the summer of 1783; recalls the details of their interview, and gives his reasons for the above request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing him of his father's death and giving an account of his last hours; his mother in a precarious state of health; encloses a letter with a request from Mr. Garden, an old friend of his father.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Dr. [John] Jeffries entrusted to his care.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just heard of Franklin's presence at Southampton; expects to be with him soon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introduced to Franklin the previous year by his uncle, Mr. David Barclay; reminds him of a request made then to appoint an American Agent on the Isle of Thanet; strongly recommends Mr. Thomas Blackburn for the position.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promising to forward his baggage as well as Mr. [Jean Antoine] Houdon's by the first conveyance; question of his account. Wishing him a speedy and happy voyage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the enclosed letter from Capt. [Thomas] Truxton by special messenger; his good opinion of the Captain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending her adieus to Franklin on his departure from France. For a long time previous the thought of his departure had grieved and saddened her. The reality almost breaks her heart. Will never again find a friend like him. Her husband, her daughters and herself will always remember his kindness and friendship for them all. Wishes him a happy voyage.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, Jan., 1907, 433.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressions of the warmest affection. Anxious concerning the long voyage ahead of him; begging him to return and occupy his old room; messages to his grandson.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their sorrow at parting from him; her regret at leaving with him no remembrance save the ginger-cake. Her sister [Georgiana Shipley Hare]'s disappointment at not seeing him. Will make the verses an excuse for writing again.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 219; Bigelow, IX, 203).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His happiness at seeing Franklin in such good health at Southampton. Renews the subject of the confiscation of his estates in North Carolina; thinks such treatment must reflect not only on that State but on all the others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Glad that Franklin was pleased with the letter he was able to procure him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Miss [Catherine Louisa] Shipley, and one to Mr. [Jonathan] Williams [Jr.] from Mr. Alexander. Important results of the revolution in America. Will be glad to hear any news concerning his interests in North Carolina, or concerning his proposals to Congress relative to copper coins.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending the bearer, who is not only a good practical farmer, but an excellent coach master; his intention to take some carriages with him to America and buy some horses upon his arrival. Messages from the [Benjamin] Wests and from Lady Strachan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cherishes all his letters; he is her Saint whose relies must be sacredly preserved; their undying memory of him and affection for him.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, Jan., 1907, 431.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Awaits impatiently the news of Franklin's safe arrival. Disposition made of certain of Franklin's effects. The character of his house entirely changed; nothing but princes and princesses, duchesses and marquises. Makes a suggestion to have large ships so constructed in America that they could come right up the Seine to Paris, laden with timber; thinks there would be profit in such an enterpirse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Description of his return journey after taking leave of Franklin; met by innumerable inquiries from all of Franklin's friends. Condition of the Chateau de la Muette; question of selling the piano-forte. His appreciation of the privilege of having lived with Franklin; his sorrow at losing him and his hope of seeing him return.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Did not follow Franklin's advice to find a consoler; too much grieved by his departure; her children share her sorrow; pleasure she has in possessing his table.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's kind letter from Southampton. Envies Mrs. [Mary] Hewson the agreeable society awaiting her in Philadelphia; wishes he were going too; his ungrateful country has done nothing for him. Surprised to hear that the gay Monsieur [William] Temple [Franklin] has retired to the plough.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a bill for £4,500, which he finds it impossible to negotiate in Paris; begs Franklin to cash it for him; promises to repay the money fifteen days or a month before the note's maturity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed of Franklin's flying visit by her family; could not have borne to see him embark for America, unless she had hopes of going there soon herself; if Franklin gives them the least encouragement, she and her husband will sail for America in the spring; describes her plan of renting a farm near Philadelphia; weary of their present vagabond life; begs for information as to rent, the price of provisions, etc.; asks his advice on many points.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prevented, by absence, from hearing of Franklin's short stay at Southampton. Question of promoting good will and a good understanding between their two countries. Messages from his family.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in works (Sparks, X, 221; Bigelow, IX, 204).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a debt due her and her husband by the State of South Carolina; recounts the particulars and begs Franklin's influence on their behalf.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prevented by illness from taking leave of Franklin; his grief at losing him; begs for his continued friendship and for information of any new processes discovered in printing, or new books on the subject; acknowledging the book sent him by Franklin's son.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a copy of their proceedings during the current year. Requests him to recommend L. Carles, one of their members who had gone to America and was then at Mole St. Nicolas, to Chevalier de la Luzerne, Governor of that colony.
(In French. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him upon his return to America.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 225; Bigelow, IX, 262).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning arrears of pay due him for his services in America; wishes to send his certificates to Philadelphia and receive in return the new certificates on which interest is paid annually by M. [Ferdinand] Grand.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his safe arrival and welcoming him to his native country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his safe arrival; hopes shortly to do this in person .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his return home. Hopes the evening of his life will resemble Franklin's; feels sure he has never given Franklin reason to regret having been his patron and introducer into America. Prevented from coming to Philadelphia by an interesting affair with Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No news yet of him. Marriage of Mlle. Brillon. Experiments with green wax; desires his son to send him a tun of this wax. Peace between Holland and Germany. Wishes he might live to see the future of America; reflections on that country. Affectionate messages from his family.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Ogden, Rev'd Uzal. Newark, N. J

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his safe arrival; feels that he is voicing the desire of the whole State in expressing gratitude for Franklin's eminent services in the cause of freedom; begs his acceptance of two pamphlets just published.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his safe return; hopes he places in Frankin; good wishes for his future welfare.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petition, as agent, for the heirs and representatives of John Striepers, relative to his claims to land in Pennsylvania and certain lots in the above city originally purchased by John Striepers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Welcoming him home; acknowledging his favors of February 8th and April 3d from Paris; would gladly embrace any opportunity of bettering himself under his patronage; desires to know under whtat conditions he aided Mr. [James] Parker; hopes to wait upon him in person.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed that the [American] Philosophical Society meets that evening; desires to lay his papers before them; begs leave to postpone sending them to Franklin until the following morning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him upon his safe arrival; France and America equally in his debt for the friendship formed between those two countries; the value of his counsels and experience. Hopes soon to pay his respects to him at Philadelphia and renew his acquaintance with Mr. and Mrs. [Richard] Bache.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Georgiana [Shipley Hare]'s verses [4p.]; Georgiana's marriage and the unfortunate circumstances connected with it. News of Sir William Jones. The Slopers at present visiting them. Prefers America to Ireland, there being no Dr. Franklin in the latter country. Sends him a purse with a design of stars and stripes. Report of Franklin's being sent a prisoner to Algiers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates him on his return to America. Asks him to send him an account of his son's conduct in Paris, and the cause of his tarrying there. Also wants his opinion of his son's character. Received no letter from him for four years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Purchase, by Dr. Franklin's advice, of a piece of land on Market St. [Philadelphia], by the Associates of Dr. Bray; their present wish to sell part of it; informed by Mr. [Francis] Hopkinson that a new street is to be made near their lot; desires his good offices in this affair on their behalf. Plan for establishing a school for negroes in Philadelphia. Encloses abstracts for their proceedings for the last year, and a book prepared for distribution among the blacks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Looks to him for the reestablishment of union and harmony in Pennsylvania. Cannot explain why Franklin's letters respecting his grandson [William Temple Franklin] have not been more efficacious. He and Mrs. Jay delighted at the prospect of seeing Dr. Franklin in New York.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 228; Bigelow, IX, 268).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Just returned from his long tour in the North; greatly improved in health and spirits. Sends the enclosed from the worthy Bishop [of St. Asaph].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes visiting Philadelphia that winter; looks forward to seeing Franklin. Introducing Mr. Huxham a merchant of fortune and eminence from Charleston; he is accompanied by Mr. Armstrong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brought from England five hundred pounds sterling, also letters of recommendation, from Dr. [Richard] Price; desires to take up farming; asks permission to wait upon him and receive his advice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to pay up any deficiency on Franklin's kind advances to his father.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delighted at Franklin's return to America. All her children at home except Ray who is studying law. Greatly honored by Franklin's letter; begs for one of his pictures; the one he sent met with a misfortune; will go and congratulate Sister Mecom on the good news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging letters to his brother [Julien David Le Roy] on marine affairs, and to M. Ingen Housz on a new stove for consuming the smoke. Visit paid to M. de Malesherbes in the country; translated Franklin's paper on "Stoves" for publication; curious result of lightning striking M. [Chrétien Guillaume de Lamirgnon de] Malesherbes's dove-cot. Experiments with balloons. Chemists interested in the decomposition of water.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reviews Franklin's labors for the interest and happiness of America, from the year 1754. Good wishes for his future welfare.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report of Franklin's capture by the Algerines. Incident of Cardinal de Rohan and the Queen's diamond necklace. Marriages of Mlle. Brillon. Numerous inquiries after Franklin from all his friends. Question of Franklin's memoirs.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 230; Bigelow, IX, 270).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the request of William Vernon, Esq., late of the Navy Board of the United States, sends his letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his safe return. Enclosing a letter from Dr. [John] Shuttleworth who has lost considerable property through the confiscation laws; his intention of bringing the matter before the Assembly; thinks the Doctor's interview with Franklin at Passy will carry great weight if endorsed by a line from Franklin; begs this favor for his friend.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delighted at the reception accorded Franklin; congratulates him on all that he has done for America; recalls the old days when their small Club used to meet; all gone now except Franklin and himself. News of his family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The great advantages of his steamboat; desires Franklin's assistance in introducing another useful art into the world.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 232).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the retention, by Revenue Officers at Martinique, of a cargo of negroes landed there by their ship "Fire-brand"; these slaves will be sold unless a heavy duty is paid on every one; protest against such treatment and beg Franklin's good offices with the French Government; aware this is an unfavorable subject with which to trouble him; can only assure him that this trade in negroes was purely accidental.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the arrears of pay due Col. Cambray; will obtain a certificate for the full amount including interest and transmit it to Col. Cambray by whatever channel Franklin advises.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin upon his safe arrival and on his election as President of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania; good wishes for his future welfare.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his auspicious return to the Nation whose independence he has principally contributed to establish. Has not received one farthing of the principal or interest of the thousands owing him by the united States; his estate almost ruined; can't afford to leave it to pay his respects to Franklin. Great hopes from Franklin's election as head of Pennsylvania; thinks he alone can reconcile parties and bring peace to that divided land.

did.physdesc: A.L.S. Nath[anie]l Falconer, John M'Culloh, Sam[ue]l Miles, Judges of the past election. 1p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As Judges of the past election they acquaint him that he is elected Counsellor for the City of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to certify to Governor Paca certain details of their conversation at Passy; value of such testimony in enabling him to recover a part of his confiscated estate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has petitioned the Supreme Executive Council [of Pennsylvania] to appoint him head measurer of salt and grain; hopes he may meet with Franklin's approbation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for news of Franklin; all kinds of rumors flying about Paris. Recommending a young man of good family, and some talent, but no fortune.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his return to his native land; sorry he cannot enjoy the repose he had so amply earned. Their removal from the country to New York; news of his family; deaths and marriages. Praise for young Mr. [William Temple] Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been ill but hopes to wait upon Franklin in a day or two relative to Dr. Ingen Housz's business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Confined for seven months past without trial, on suspicion of a trifling offense; his services in the American navy; has applied to the Navy Office for the prize-money due him; informed that they could not settle his claims until they received the returns from Franklin; begs his assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a copy of a memorial now before Congress, concerning a plan for the settlement of a new state.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering him wines of the first quality.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Widow of James Robinson, who commanded the ship which carried Franklin to England. During his Continental service, her husband captured a schooner bound from Providence to New York, which was taken from him by the French fleet; this action approved of by Mr. Livingston and later by Congress; desires to wait on Franklin in reference to this affair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pleasure with which she heard of his arrival; all her father's relatives dead but Dr. Franklin; begs him to write to her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed of Franklin's arrival in America; his enthusiastic reception and his improved state of health; all Paris rejoiced at the news. Prophesies that his presence will infuse new life into the [American] Philosophical Society of Philadelphia. Death of his eldest brother. Experiments with balloons.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His views concerning the election of bishops; his objections to the non-giving bishops of Scotland; his reasons for wishing that the first American bishops should receive their consecration from English bishops. Acknowledging the information concerning the abbreviated liturgy; reasons why the Psalms cannot be curtailed.
(In duplicate.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed, for the most part, in Mass. Hist. Soc. Collections, III, 162.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on his election [as President of the Supreme Executive Council of Pennsylvania].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Keen pleasure felt by Franklin's friends at the reception accorded him in Philadelphia; compares his entry to the ancient triumphs at Rome, to the latter's disadvantage. Reminds him of his promise to write the memoirs of his life; insists on the importance of such a work. Tremendous jealousy and dissension caused by Franklin's writing to one fair friend and ignoring the other; humorous account of the affair. Occupations of the Court at Fontaincbleau. Postponement of the Cardinal de Rohan's trial.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes his petition to the Supreme Executive Council, asking to be appointed Notary Public, will meet with Franklin's approbation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on his late appointment [as President of Pennsylvania]; fears the burden of such an office will be too great a tax on his health. Question concerning type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been so ill that she doubted ever being able again to express her regard for Franklin; congratulates him on his return to America; hopes the new country will make a proper use of her independence. Introducing a relative of hers to Franklin's good offices; her husband has written also.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Submits his jeu d'esprit to his superior judgment, and he hopes it will be suppressed if not approved.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed of his arrival in his own country and the honors he has received. Her grief over their separation ineffaceable. News of her family. Praise of Franklin's character.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Putnam's Monthly, Jan., 1907, 434.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on his safe return and on his devoted services to his country. His friendship for her late husband [Peter Timothy]; has brought up her son to be worthy of the illustrious name he bears; would have sent him to see Franklin had the season not been so far advanced.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his present promotion; hopes his prudence will allay the heats and temper the ferments of parties. Concerning the wish of Franklin's grandson [William Temple Franklin] to be employed in some public office abroad; thinks he has a well-grounded claim to it; advises a seat in the National Council for a year or two as a good preparation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of a remedy for the stone. Delighted to hear of his safe arrival and flattering reception. Regrets not having been with him at Southampton. Acknowledging his election as member of the [American] Philosophical Society; desires Franklin to convey his thanks to the President and other members. Hostile aspect of affairs between England and America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petition for arrears of pay due him for his services in the American army; his pleas to Congress have elicited no reply; begs Franklin to assist him; the money will pay his debts and enable him to return to France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. [Richard] Price has entrusted to his care the accompanying book by the late Dr. Dobson. Inquires if he shall continue to pay Franklin's annual dues at the Society of Antiquaries [of London].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discharged Franklin's servant, Charles Hicks; his obvious disappointment and dissatisfaction; his loss of the Angora cat; believes he sold it. Enclosing bills of lading for various articles shipped; as to his own commission, begs Franklin to accept it.
Statement of freight, etc., on personal effects of Benjamin Franklin shipped to Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on his election as President of Pennsylvania. Account of his unfortunate treatment during Franklin's absence abroad; sued for a debt of seventeen pounds; put in gaol and all the stock of his printing-office sold; his long struggle against poverty; his present work in a printing office in Germantown; desires a candid consideration of his case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the enclosed letter from Col. Shre(e)ve, concerning the necessary repairs on the river bank; has Franklin's deed for the park, etc.; will leave it with his son, during his absence from town.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mme. de Chaumont occupies Franklin's old rooms; their constant talk of him; hopes to pay him a visit. Treaty between Holland and the [Holy Roman] Emperor, [Joseph II]; signed under the guarantee of the King of France; M. de Vergennes a great peace-maker. Disadvantages to America of a too rapid emigration. M. de la Motte occupied with medicine.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to obtain a piece of land near Pennsbury for Mrs. [Patience] Wright, to be used as a burial ground.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminds Franklin of his foodness for her as a child; her plan of printing an almanac; Mr.[Eleazer] Oswald in New York and unable to assist her; begs Franklin to provide a clever name for the almanac and to write the preface.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his safe arrival. Appreciates Franklin's good opinion of his children. Should he come to Boston, begs him to stay at his house. Concerning Franklin's bill on the late Dr. [Samuel] Cooper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Welcoming him to America and congratulating him on his appointment to the Presidency of Pennsylvania. Several months before, sent him a letter and several memoirs taken from a volume of the American Academy [of Arts and Sciences]; as soon as it is finished will transmit to him the whole volume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of XXXIII, 238, in addition, begs Franklin to obtain some support for him until he can receive payment for his certificates.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: America's task to revive and establish civil liberty. Franklin's ability to serve his country. State of the English Government. His family's love and admiration for Franklin. His high regard for the profession of a printer; glad Franklin's grandson [Benjamin Franklin Bache] is to follow in his footsteps.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 242; Bigelow, IX, 280).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her happiness at hearing of his arrival; wrote him directly but received no answer; Franklin her only relative besides her father; sends love to the family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a bill due his father by Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him by the of Mr. Slubey, a letter from the Bishop of St. Asaph; forwarded a letter from Dr. [Richard] Price.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heard with delight of his safe arrival and enthusiastic reception in America. Reminds him to speak to Congress on his behalf; his position as Resident at The Hague would obviate the necessity and expense of a Minister. Two great events since Franklin's departure; peace with the Emperor [of Austria], and the alliance of France and the Netherlands. His intimacy with the French Ambassador, M. de Verac. Promising to send him a publication, a monument to a great man and Franklin's friend.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Owing to Franklin's recommendations, procured the position of Army Surgeon during the war; acknowledges his obligation with gratitude. Enclosing a few pamphlets on an improved system of revenue; his wishes for the prosperity of Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the settlement of Mary Standley's estate; £160 due on the bond of Benjamin Franklin and Robert Grace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presented Franklin's letter to the Duc de La Vrillière. Electrometer of Mr. [William] Henly. Opinion of French chemists on Dr. [Joseph] Priestley's experiments with " l'air fine." Experiments with burning glass and its effect on gold. Expected arrival of the "Flora" with the results of his brother [Julien David Le Roy]'s experiments. Rumor that the Comte de Lauraguais has turned quaker. Begs Franklin to urge Mr. [John] Walsh to publish his experiments with the torpedo [fish].
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis-Alexandre duc de La Roche-Guyon et de. La Rocheguyon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delighted to hear of Franklin's safe arival and the ovation given him; the sentiments expressed by his countrymen are shared by France. America's need of his services; the world expects from her an example of good government. Hopes his friends will hear from him often; expressions of admiration and affection.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Knows of no administration so likely as Franklin's to restore tranquility to Pennsylvania; offers his congratulations [on his election as President of Pennsylvania].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on his appointment as President of Pennsylvania. Proposes that his cousin, William Bartram, and his nephew, Dr. Moses Marshall, should travel through the western parts of the United States, and the proposed new states, with a view to making observations on the natural productions and curiosities of those regions; desires to know if they would meet with proper support and encouragement in such an undertaking. Has sent Franklin his catalogues of forest trees and shrubs of the Thirteen United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of their infant seminary of learning at Carlisle; requests Franklin's influence and interest with the Honorable Assembly to whom they have applied for assistance; increase in the number of students and in the necessary expenses; their hope that the Legislature will either give them a sum of money or lend them two or three thousand pounds without interest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the widow of Miles Pennington, late Captain of Marines on board the ship "Reprisal"; her husband lost at sea; left penniless; has applied in vain to various authorities for the prize-money due him; begs Franklin to look into her case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the appointment of John Anstey, barrister-at-law, to repair to the United States and inquire into several claims which have been or shall be presented; desired by the Honorable the Marquis of Carmarthen to communicate Mr. Anstey's appointment to the Members of Congress and recommend him to their protection and countenance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the good news and rejoicing with him on his improved state of health. Congratulates Franklin's countrymen on his acceptance of the Presidency of Pennsylvania. Cardinal de Rohan still in prison; arrest of the Comte de Cagliostro, M. and Mme. de La Motte [Valois] and a certain Mlle. Oliva said to have impersonated the Queen; history of Mme. de La Motte [Valois]; righteous indignation of the Queen; general opinion of Cagliostro. Mesmer's loss of prestige in Paris; his failure to excite any interest in England; his present sojourn in Italy. Arrest of the Chief Secretary of Council for secretly printing attacks on the Ministers. Messages from many of Franklin's friends.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the son of Richard Croker, late of Guildford, in Surrey; informed that his uncle John Crocker came to America many years before and that his children are nephews of Franklin; desires information concerning them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin three more volumes of his work. 1
(In Italian.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, X, 233; Bigelow, IX, 273).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Settlement of his affairs likely to take some time. Receipt for making Crown soap. Mr. [James] Bowdoin's desire to read, before their Academy [of Arts and Sciences], Franklin's [Sundry] Marine [Observations]. Sends an account of a dissolvent for stone. Claim of a Mr. Allen, of Bedford, to make salt water fresh in any quantity, with the aid of machinery. Desires Dr. [John] Jeffries's memoirs and also the papers relative to stoves and smoking chimneys. No word from Mr. Benjamin Vaughan concerning the books for the Franklin Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about his health. Quotes some verses on human misery and the ills man has to suffer in old age. Hopes he will live long to finish his work. Gives him a budget of news about political and public events in Paris; refers to the affair of the diamond necklace. Mesmer and his disciple, Deslon, still have many partisans. Extravagant costumes worn by men and women. Mme. de Maucomeil has taken the house occupied by Franklin when in Paris. Tells him about the de Chaumont family, the Le Veillard family, Mme. Helvétius, Abbés Laroque and Rochon and all his old friends and former neighbors. M. Brillon, his wife and two daughters with the latters' husbands all living together in Paris. Wishes Franklin could get loans of money for the United States like M. [Charles Alexandre] de Calonne, in France. New coinage of gold pieces.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging clemency on behalf of a poor prisoner, who prays that he may be set free from an unmerited captivity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the candles he has been making; describes the separation of the smoke and flame, and their issuing from different ends of the candle; reason for this.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of a letter of recommendation written for him by Vicar-General Christian of the Isle of Man; solicits employment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Leaves Philadelphia next morning. Will take any commands Franklin may have for New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a passport to England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for the letter of recommendation Franklin was good enough to procure him for New Orleans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has inquired about the two chaise bearers. They will call on Franklin for his orders if he wishes to go out.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting invitation to dine with Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Present political situation in Ireland. His experiments in making a balloon; queries concerning aerial navigation. War between Holland and the Emperor, [Joseph II] inevitable. Anxious to hear of la Fayette's safe arrival in France; expects a visit from him. Request for letters of introduction to Franklin's friends in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a Canadian, begs assistance to go to Montreal to rejoin his family.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the widow of one of Dr. Franklin's former post riders. Being reduced to poverty, asks his aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They have erased his name from John Cram's subscription paper and return his grateful thanks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has replied to his correspondent, Mercator; desire of a friend of his to have this speech and the preceding ones printed; sends them to Franklin for his inspection; indebted to him for his best ideas. Awaits his consent for the reading of the Maritime pamphlet before their Society. [American Academy of Arts and Sciences.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his arrival in America with his son, and several of his master mechanics; kind reception given him by General [John] Sullivan, to whom he presented Franklin's letter. Description of the mercantile establishment he expects to build up; prophesies that in twenty years America will manufacture all her own goods; desires him to write to Gen. Sullivan about the establishment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her husband's service in the navy; left a widow without means; nearly five hundred dollars owing to her husband [Philip Gaudin]; has waited in vain for the Congress to do something for the widows of those slain in the war; begs Franklin to take pity on her distressed situation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed that Franklin's printing material has arrived; desires to know on what conditions he can be furnished with certain type; offers to come to Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Glories in his friendship and confidence; comments made on his bust. Irish politics; his reasons for wishing to retire from Parliament on the next election; denounces Ord's Jesuitical Bill. The Duchess the gayest female that ever reigned on the island; numerous and disagreeable reports of America appearing in the English papers; wishes sufficient trustworthy information to publicly contradict these statements.
